snippet: On Wednesday, Washington is expected to give a boost to the court when the State Department offers a reward for information on fugitives in atrocity cases and issues a list of names that will include the court’s most-wanted.
abstract: State Department plans to pay up to $5 million for information leading to arrests of fugitives in atrocity cases and will issue list of names that for first time will include some of fugitives most wanted by the International Criminal Court in the Hague; move comes as boost to court, which United States at one time scorned.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Washington is expected to give a boost to the court when the State Department offers a reward for information on fugitives in atrocity cases and issues a list of names that will include the court’s most-wanted.

headline.seo: U.S. Assists International Criminal Court, but Still Has No Intention of Joining It
headline.main: U.S. Grows More Helpful to International Criminal Court, a Body It First Scorned
headline.print_headline: U.S. Grows More Helpful to International Criminal Court, a Body It First Scorned

keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
keywords.name: subject
